description: From Middle English repeten, from Old French repeter, from Latin repetō, repetere, from the prefix re- (“again”) + peto (“attack, beseech”).

examples: We gave up after the third repeat because it got boring.

entries.meaning: A television program shown after its initial presentation; a rerun.
(medicine, pharmacy) A refill of a prescription.
(genetics, biochemistry) A pattern of nucleic acids that occur in multiple copies throughout a genome (or of amino acids in a protein).
(music) A mark in music notation directing a part to be repeated.

verbs.description: repeat (third-person singular simple present repeats, present participle repeating, simple past and past participle repeated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To do or say again (and again).
examples: The scientists repeated the experiment in order to confirm the result.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To echo the words of (a person).
(intransitive) To strike the hours, as a watch does.
(obsolete) To make trial of again; to undergo or encounter again.
examples: He […]  repeats the danger of the burning town.

entries.meaning: (law, Scotland) To repay or refund (an excess received).

(procedure word, military) To call in a previous artillery fire mission with the same ammunition and method either on the coordinates or adjusted either because destruction of the target was insufficient or missed.
examples: Use "say again" instead of repeat on the radio. Repeat will bring in artillery fire.

entries.meaning: To commit fraud in an election by voting more than once for the same candidate.
